participants.participant: Dr. Gurdon Wattles, Head of Investor Relations

plist.p: Ladies and gentlemen, I am Vicky the operator for this conference. Welcome to the Deutsche Bank Third Quarter 2009 Analyst Conference Call. Please note that for the duration of the presentation, all participants will be in listen-only mode and the conference is being recorded. After the presentation, there will be an opportunity to ask questions. .
At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Dr. Gurdon Wattles. Please go ahead, sir.

Thank you, Vicky and thank you everyone for joining. Good morning. Welcome to the Deutsche Bank third quarter results call. A little after 7:00 this morning European Time we put the PowerPoint charts, the earnings release and the interim report on the web and Stefan Krause the group's CFO is now going to take us through the selection of PowerPoint charts which were published.

After that we are going to turn it over to Q&A. We have a large number of participants on the call and I would ask for your understanding and in fairness to all participants make sure as many people as possible get to put their questions if we could say two questions per questioner. Thank you for your understanding on that. Anything that we don't cover then, please go ahead and call the IR department and we will make sure your questions get answered.
At this point I would like hand over to Stefan Krause to take us through some of the charts Stefan please go ahead.

Thank you, Gurdon, and also from my part good morning, ladies and gentlemen, from Berlin today, not from Frankfurt as we had our supervisory board meeting yesterday here with the results that we informed you about yesterday night. So also welcome back to those that were on the call, yesterday. I would like to quickly go through the slides in the usual manner and then obviously I am happy to answer any questions you may have.

If we start on page three, our group performance, we did have revenues of 7.2 billion in the quarter, a lower provision for credit losses of 544 million versus the previous quarter, income before income taxes of 1.3 billion, and a net income of 1.4 billion as we had announced. This results in diluted EPS of €2.10 and pre-tax return on average equity of 15%.

On our capital and balance sheet, our Tier 1 ratio grew once more. We have now several consecutive quarters of Tier 1 growth to 11.7% and a core Tier 1 ratio for the first time above the 8% with 8.1%. We have reduced risk-weighted assets of 288 billion and total assets down 4% again to 1.66 billion (sic) [1.66 trillion]. And in our US GAAP pro forma calculation total assets were also down with €915 billion. Our leverage ratio of 25 times continues to be within the target range.

On the liquidity and funding, with this quarter we completely finished our funding plan for 2009 with a total of 60 billion of capital market issued and we continue to have a very good cash and liquidity position.

Slide four is a summary of our results. For year to date we have achieved an EBIT of 4.4 billion and a pre-tax return on equity per target definition of 18%. Our EPS at 5.62 three times the first nine months of 2008 and our dividend accrual remains at the rate of prior year's dividend as in the first and second quarter

As you know we don't take a decision until year end, then the board recommends to the supervisory board what dividend proposal should go to the AGM and that's why it is our tradition to just accrue to the previous year's dividend.

Our pre tax return on equity per target definition is marginally lower than reported. We had a gain on the sale of Daimler AG of course, which is excluded as you know from our from our usual target definition.

On page five, we show our net revenue at 7.2 billion for the quarter, that included a negative impact from Ocala, the transaction in Florida of approximately €350 million. We had some impact of some other specific items, which we will cover in the respective business segment discussion.

On page six, we show now our provision for credit losses that were 544 million in the third quarter of 2009 and as you can see substantially reduced from second quarter levels. Of this, investment banking credit provisions are 323 million, including 250 million due to reclassified assets under IAS 39.

IAS 39 provisions are, as I have told you in previous discussions, mainly situation specific individual provisions and certainly this is not a calculation that shows any trends as we are working on the specific assets that were reclassified.
In PCAM our reserves is 240 million, which are almost entirely related to our retail business within PBC. I will talk about the IAS 39 and PBC credit environment in a few minutes if you bear with me.

On page seven, we cover our non-interest expenses as a whole. Our total non-interest expenses were 5.4 billion in the third quarter. Our compensation expenses were reduced versus the prior quarter. The delta is mainly related to the lower severance. As you remember in the second quarter call I had told you that the bulk of severance that we applied this year in order to do some of the restructuring we went through, was mainly expensed and would affect the second quarter, you will see in the third quarter significantly lower.

In the current quarter, our G&A expenses included a provision of 200 million, which is related to the bank's offer to repurchased certain products from private investors. To give you the background on this, due to a technical problem that we had in the composition of the underlying portfolio of the fund, the bank intends to restructure this fund. And because the relevant close end funds contained illiquid assets, the bank has decided to offer a repurchase of the product so as to provide investors with an exit from investment in that situation. Again, it's an offer as you restructure. We do not know how many of our investors will make use of that offer at this point in time, but we have taken a reserve for it.

Other non-compensation expenses were 364 million in the quarter this was effect mainly the policyholder benefits and claims, in respect of the bank's investment in Abbey Life, which as you know always is a cash flow item which is offset by a corresponding amount in the revenue lines or just a hedge. But it was substantial this quarter because of the market environment that basically leads to the valuation of this number.

On compensation let me clarify one issue, obviously we have had a long compensation discussion going on right now and how new compensation structure will look like. For us the most important principle is that we would like to continue to attract and retain top talent and obviously we would like to keep to market practices here. We will keep a compensation system that is mainly driven by what is happening in the market, that's why we're closely monitoring competitor actions.

We definitely also, as some of our competitors have announced, have the intent to gain full compliance with G-20 and FSB guidelines. We had done already some of that in 2008, to highlight some of the main issues; obviously, we're looking at base salary versus variable. We're looking at stock versus restricted cash. We're looking at multiyear deferrals. We are looking at claw back provisions for senior people and obviously we are also looking at robust governance mechanisms that ensure independence of the decision makers around compensation items.

On page eight, we show our solid profitability. I think we can definitely say, if we look at the first nine months, it is a quantum leap forward from the year 2008 and we have therefore significantly recovered from the bad situation we went through in 2008.

On page nine, the net income of €1.4 billion, reflects a tax benefit of 78 million that does include some positive outcome of the tax audit settlements that were though partly offset by some revaluation of deferred tax positions which then resulted in a net benefit of 369 million.

In addition like every quarter we have some tax exempt income which was about 174 million in the quarter. It's mainly related to the sale of our Daimler shares and the Postbank equity pick up, and as you know we do annualize this tax expense and that was about in the same level in the quarter.

Including these specific effects and an accounting adjustment for this annualization of the tax exempt income, our ETR would have been in accordance with the range of our mid-term guidance of 30 to 35%, approximately. So on the full year, though, we now believe and the guidance we'll give you now on the ETR is that we definitely believe that we will stay now below 20% based on this significant one-off we had in this quarter.

On page 10, we show a chart that we are obviously specifically proud of, our ability deliver increased capital ratios has been proven once more in the third quarter of 2009. We now have the highest Tier 1 ratio since the introduction of the Basel standards. The core Tier 1 ratio, which excludes the hybrids has also increased to 8.1, this is therefore for the first time above the 8% threshold.

Risk weighted assets have continued to decrease versus prior quarter end driven by, on the one hand obviously FX effects on the one hand, but also by asset reduction as we have and have continued to de-risk the bank.

Sal. Oppenheim, as I said yesterday, we continue to be very confident that the acquisition of Sal. Oppenheim will not stress our sore Tier 1 ratio. We have on the one hand two more quarters of retained earnings. And the second obviously, as I told you yesterday, I showed you a maximum of the Tier 1 impact we expect and as we go now into the closing process you can assume that we will continue to work on reducing that Tier 1 impact.

On page 11, we show the Tier 1 capital development. Here obviously in the third quarter, the highlight is our hybrid security issuance of 1.3 billion and then combined with our net income – our positive net income, our capital generation was 2.7 billion. And I show on the chart it was offset by FX effects, equity based compensation because we had the vesting in that account in August. And then obviously our pension plan accounting change that we did in the fourth quarter last year that now shows the volatility that we had made you aware of.

On page 12, we show our total assets development. We have continued to strictly mange our asset base, our IFRS assets decreased 4% to 1.66 trillion. Our pro-forma U.S. GAAP assets, which are mainly adjusted for, as you know, derivative nettings and other nettings, decreased to 915 billion at a slower pace than before, but we have continued to be able to deal with the bank and therefore lower our balance sheet volumes.

Our leverage ratio, the 25 times, that's in line with target. It is slightly up versus second quarter, because obviously on the one hand our equity has increased, but – and our U.S. GAAP pro-forma balance sheet has reduced, however, our pro forma fair value gains that we apply on the capital calculation on owned debt have almost halved in the quarter.

If I go – move on now to page 13. As you know, this is the other part of our bank's balance sheet that we remain very confident and that we based on the strengths of the bank is our funding position that remained very strong compared to the beginning of the crisis. We continue to focus on the high portion of our unsecured funding and stable funding sources and we have completed, as I talked you at the beginning, our capital markets and retail deposits funding plan for the year already in the third quarter. So we don't expect any further measures to be taken in the fourth quarter of this year.

Our cash and liquidity reserves exceed and continue to exceed our short-term wholesale funding of 76 billion, so good liquidity position overall. For 2010, we have relatively modest funding needs. Obviously we will have some capital market maturities that in our view can be funded without difficulty as things stand. We have to keep in mind that obviously, our significant balance sheet reduction that has gone on since the beginning of the crisis has also eased up this part of our business.
Let me now cover some of the segment results and page 15 now illustrates the P&L in our CB&S segment and let me highlight some of the specific items that we had in the third quarter CB&S results.

The CB&S results reflect, as I had told you previously, approximately 350 million related to the Ocala Funding situation, a commercial paper vehicle in Florida, as you know. I think you've read in the newspaper all about this transactions. It also shows the 300 million in losses related to specific risks that we have covered in our structured credit business. These negative effects on the one hand were partly counterbalanced by some net mark-ups mainly related, by the way, to our other favorite topic of the monolines which is 390 million of which 263 million were booked in sales and trading debt.

We only had 38 million fair value losses on debt in sales and trading equity that's where we booked it. CB&S expenses include a charge of 200 million to the already specified banks offer to repurchase this certain investment product I mentioned already.

On page 16, I detail now the sales and trading revenues. Without the impact of the above mentioned items, especially the Ocala Funding then also the losses related to the write-downs on the specific risk in structured credit and the monoline driven mark-ups, if I take all those effects together our sales and trading revenues would have been higher by approximately 400 million and this is all in sales and trading debt, which shows you the strength of this business in the third quarter.

Despite these effects our sales and trading revenues are therefore really at a record level, 9% higher than the previous record in 2005. And against the second quarter it was a lower drop than the normal seasonal drop of 16% that we would've expected for the traditionally weaker Q3 results.

And I think that what is especially impressive is that result now has really been achieved despite significant balance sheet and risk weighted asset reduction of which 40% and 20% respectively from peak level, so significant reduction in assets has not led into a cut in revenues, to the opposite have led to record levels of revenues.

Risk weighted assets and our value at risk, we have further reduced from the second quarter to complete the picture at lower asset base with less risk, our revenue base is very strong, which shows the current strong margin situation we are experienced. We also have reduced some of our Tier risk through the de-risking of legacy assets as our business is more client focused.

And now, on page 17, I go to sales and trading debt revenues that were 2.2 billion without the net effects of the specific items I just mentioned, debt, sales and trading revenues would have been 2.6 billion. Our recent markdowns are related to legacy credit assets which result in several billion risk weighted asset reduction in the coming quarters.

Margins as you see them have continued to normalize from the peak levels, but are approximately depending on different type of product between 10 to 60% above the pre-crisis level. And something we are also very proud about in the current market environment, we have been to increase market share in the U.S. and Europe across all major products including FX, rates and credit.

For example to give you some examples, according Greenwich and Euromoney, we're number one in global FX and we are number one in all major regions in this, in fact we're number one in European interest rate derivatives, number one in European investment grade credit, number three in U.S. fixed income and number three in U.S. interest rate derivatives. So, overall very good scorings.

In credit by the way, we had our best quarter since 2007 in our businesses despite the fact or including the effect that our new strategy of creating more flow and client focused business has certainly completely paid-off.

Our unique emerging markets local franchise has also produced excellent results across the board and now we're regaining the benefit from our ongoing investment in commodities with offices in Houston and Calgary expanding our range of products and services for our clients, so really good results across the board in that area of the business.

On page 18, the same good development in sales and trading equity, this is our best quarterly revenue performance since 2007 of the peers that have disclosed, we rank number three globally by Q3 revenues. That's really a strong and great position that we have and historically certainly a big step forward.

Despite some of the market normalization, our results were 2% higher than second quarter and we did include here 38 million of fair value losses on debt. Investment in cash equities is paying off. We're improving and continue to improve our position in the U.S.

In July we won the Euromoney award for best equity house in North America and according to Bloomberg we have now 6% market share to compare out of 4% market share in 2007. We were voted the World's Best Prime Broker by hedge funds and global custodian prime brokerages survey. In derivatives our focus has shifted towards more flow and listed derivatives. In Asia, we won a number of equity derivatives awards from Asia Risk. In our prop trading, a substantial reduction of risk, as we had discussed in previous quarters and notional capital. Therefore obviously when you look at these great results in both trading areas, our – we definitely have an improved asset efficiency and – as we've also been able to achieve a much lower risk appetite as you can see one page 19.

Our revenues per asset are now nearly three times the 2005 levels. We have reduced our asset base significantly versus pre-crisis levels, as I have outlined. Risk weighted assets have been reduced by nearly 20% compared to prior year levels. Our VaR has come down, our constant input VaR, which means adjusted for the impact of market data after it has decreased to its lowest levels since the beginning of the crisis and is over 50% lower than in the peak about a year ago.

On page 20, we show you our Origination and Advisory revenues. We have also produced a solid quarter. M&A activity in the industry remain very low. Our business in this area benefited from strong equity origination performance which was, by the way, the best since the second quarter of 2007. And a very good investment grade market driven by strong customer demand for debt and equity market issuance products, as you know, I'm sure – you all are aware of.
If we move on page 21 to our GTB business segment, it delivered 194 million, even under high pressure we have a very high pre-tax return on equity in this business.

On page 22, I give you some more details about the performance in Global Transaction Banking, the business obviously, remained exposed to the low interest rate environment and the low corporate activity as a whole, that's significantly negatively impacting the business for GTB.

Of course, on the other hand and that's a technical effect I need to make you aware of, GTB benefit from our risk based funding effect of about €63 million because of its refined funding methodology I already mentioned in the last call. That was valid for second quarter 2009, but obviously not for 2008 and on a year-on-year comparison there is a difference in the definition of the profits of Global Transaction Banking. Again the impact was €63 million

Of course, on a Group level, yeah, there is a corresponding debit; on a Group level this evens out. So the Group level numbers are not impacted, it's just an internal, different allocation of our funding costs.

We recently, as you know, announced that we now have signed heads of an agreement to acquire the ABN AMRO commercial banking activities in the Netherlands. We do believe that the combination will create a powerful platform for our clients. We therefore will become the fourth largest provider of corporate investment banking service in the Netherlands; obviously, assuming that we can complete this – finally complete this transaction that we have waited so long for.

On page 23, I come now to PCAM and the good news is that Asset and Wealth Management has returned to profitability with a pre-tax profit of 134 million. And this was mainly driven by the absence of specific charges, but also by some initial positive effect from the recalibration measures across these businesses and platforms and we saw also some more customer activity and the improving markets show already first sign of – positive signs in the profit development in this business area.

On page 24, Asset Management's performance was again driven by the higher market levels and tightening spreads, which led to an increase in retail revenues and performance fees, mostly in Europe. We have again right sized our global platform. Since we started restructuring in November of last year, more than 600 people have left already that platform, which represents about 18% of the workforce in that business area.

Our net new money in Asset Management was 5 billion. PWM performance also continued to recover, driven by the stable revenue base and a positive contribution from the risk-based funding. The effect was much smaller, obviously, than in GTB, but we had an effect here. Since September of last year, we have reduced our head count by more than 300 people, primarily in Asia in this business. Net new money generation in PWM was €5 billion, an annualized growth rate based on invested assets of about 11% growth rate.

We see all the specific items predominately behind us in this business area, obviously are making this statements assuming that we will not have a significant change in market. To complete, while the risk-based funding had a negative charge to Asset Management of about 6 million, the risk-based funding had a positive effect of about 18 million in PWM.

On the next slide, we go into our private and business clients' P&L. They reported an income before income taxes of 149 million. If you go to page 26, the revenues were impacted by this continued wariness of retail investors around the uncertainties in markets right now, and also obviously impacted by the low interest margin situation we have. This was obviously only partially counterbalanced by some revenue increase we had in our credit product.

The provision for credit losses decreased slightly versus the last quarter, obviously as we have focused and had some more rigorous management activities and collection efforts that showed some positive effects. We see some additional severance in Q4, but relatively modest. We have done obviously some restructuring around mid-year. Obviously through the delays that severance package originate, we see some of people walking off the platform only at the beginning of next year.
Again, expenses decreased, mainly driven by this reduction of the severance payments, and I think that was the biggest effect in their cost. PBC had also securities inflows of about €1 billion.
As here on page 27, we now show you the described net money flows by quarter and we spread it out by our three different business divisions that you see that we have been able to grow our asset base.

Let me now go into last part of my presentation and cover quickly some key current issues. And I think we come now to the main and most favorite topic of the market around Deutsche Bank. Right now, we have taken – I really would like to say it once more, we have taken a lot of time. And we've done a lot of math and we've looked at worst case scenarios, likely scenarios. We have looked at all the measures that we've taken. We looked at all the regulation that's coming. We've looked at the structuring of the business. We have really done a company-wide very extensive research on our capital base, on the future, on our long range planning, on what our risk-weighted assets will look like in the future. And again, with done this – doing this review and looking at possible new rules, expected new rules, but as I show you on page 29, also looking at effects that will counter the increase in – driven on risk-weighted assets, looking at our business plans, etcetera we can – I can overall reaffirm that our target of the Tier 1 ratio of above 10% on a going forward basis, we will be able to achieve despite the headwinds we might have in terms of higher risk-weighted assets and we are including now what I would call the double punishment scenario that on the one hand we will see an increase in risk-weighted assets and second we will see an increase in ratios as well, which at the same time is a double punishment and we continue to stick to our statement that we are fine on the capital front as you look into our planning and the only comment we have been making for this is any acquisitions that we have to make certainly will require then capital measures.

On page 30, I give you the usual disclosure on the loan book, maybe we cover some of the specific questions that may arise. In the questions, we've included here the IAS reclassified assets and we show you in which buckets they sit. And deliver therefore also an explanation why this portfolio has been more impacted by loan loss provisions.
In the different manner it's not run rate loan loss provisions, it's one-time specific items, I will gladly answer any further questions you have about our loan book and discuss it in questions.

I show now the pro forma impact on IAS 39 reclassifications on page 31, as you know we are obliged to that and just mentioning it briefly you saw the significant decrease that we had in the gap between accrual accounting and mark-to-market accounting that went from 6 billion, both in capital and P&L down to 4.2 billion a reduction of 1.8 billion. So the expected narrowing of the gap between the mark-to-market driven in illiquid markets, in our view a wrong valuation of this effort is now closing the gap. On the other hand, of course, any loan loss provisions that we take on this portfolio are also helping to reduce this gap. As you saw, we have not further reclassified any assets in the third quarter.

On page 32, we show the problem loans. IFRS impaired loans have risen by about 100 million since the second quarter, due to increases which were largely offset by charge-offs and repayments. Problem loans were up by 500 million, materially all loans – these are loans where the borrower is in financial difficulty, basically, but these exposures are either collateralized or guaranteed. So despite the fact that we had this significant increase, I could almost call it a no risk or risk free increase because of the type of loans that have gone into that bucket.

Our impaired loan coverage, which excludes collateral, rose to 47% and if you would exclude the much lumpier IAS 39 reclassified loans, coverage before collateral improved to 59%, which is very much in line with our European peers.

On page 33, we wanted to give you some sense for how our delinquency ratio development is also to explain mainly effective. We do see the same effect that some of our competitors have reported with rising delinquencies mainly in consumer portfolios. At the same time, if you look at the mortgage portfolio you see how stable it has developed throughout the crisis only slight increases, but not material increases. And then if you look at the small corporate book, we also see the reported increases in delinquencies. But now, again, because mortgage the loan book represents about 70% of our PBC loan book, that's the explanation why we continue to track below reserve levels of our competition. Something to do with, obviously, how our loan book is built-up and what assets it comprises. So we have just higher asset positions on those assets that run lower delinquencies.

On monoline exposure, good news in the third quarter, overall our monoline fair value exposure before CVA was reduced by 1.8 billion in the quarter. As you can see from the chart, here on the chart we put the two quarter comparisons on the reserving logic. We do our reserves against this exposure will also reduce by 945 million.

The overall notional amount of our monoline insurance is down approximately 30% from its peak, 29% from its peak, driven by the expected roll off of the high quality corporate CDOs which have had a short maturity and again by the previously mentioned significant settlement and commutation of contracts with – to monolines.

So you see in the highest risk bucket the non-investment grade monolines, that contains the highest risk category of the assets. Basically, we are at nil exposure by end of the third quarter. And reserve levels in all other buckets remain at the previous quarter levels.

So on page 35, to really sum up and we always like this chart, because it shows the progress of Deutsche Bank throughout the quarters of the crisis from year ago, our position has continued to improve significantly. We're considerably more profitable despite the fact that we continue to absorb quite a significant amount of charges related to legacy positions.

Some of our businesses have been recalibrated, we have taken risk down. We have taken leverage down. We have improved our operating performance. We have increased our Tier-1 capital ratio, which is at the highest level it ever has been. Our core capital has also steadily improved and again, I reiterate again some of the feedback we received to Sal. Oppenheim acquisition does not concern us in that regard as we will be able to manage down this 85 basis points and our balance sheet efficiency has therefore significantly improved also in historic context. So bottom line a bank that's less leveraged, that's better capitalized, that shows lower risk, but at the same time shows higher profitability.
Thank you very much. And I am open for any questions you may have now.
Thank you, Stefan. Can we have the first question please?
. The first question is from Mr. Christopher Wheeler, MainFirst Bank. Please go ahead sir.

Yes. Good morning. And well done on good set of results, obviously. My couple of questions are about, well, first of all the asset management business. Again, obviously a much improved performance. However, if I just extrapolate some of the numbers, it appears to me that the gross margin on your asset management piece in the first nine months was about 30 basis points and then if I strip out, what I think might be 60 basis points on the retail element it appears the rest of the assets under management earned about 15 basis points. You've talked about the cost cutting, the job change – job losses, but it appears to me with the cost ratio in the combined entity of private and wealth management still up in the 80s, you still seem some way off even in improving markets from having the right cost base to match the revenue opportunity in that business. And I am sorry to keep going on about this every quarter, but perhaps you could just give us some flavor as to how you are going to get that cost income ratio to perhaps where it should be?

And the second question just relating to the same area of business, you kindly gave us some indication as to how private wealth management has actually done at a pre tax level in the last two quarters. Can you tell us whether you actually did make money? I guess you did, perhaps give us some feel for the extent of that profitability in the quarter? Thank you.

Okay. Thank you, Christopher for your questions. Let me cover this asset management business. Number one, you are completely right. That business continues to be exposed to the crisis. We do have obviously lower fee income and that continued. It did improve somewhat in the third quarter. We still obviously lack to a large extent also the performance fee component and our business model is certainly more performance fee skewed than it is base fee skewed and therefore obviously as markets recover, we might see higher margins in that business, hopefully as the performance fee component kicks-in. But at the same time this is one of the discussions that we had in the bank in terms of recalibrating this business is moving it further away from the performance fee concept and more into a regular fee concept.

What have we done in terms of restructuring and changing this business, you wanted some of these components, is we have done a lot of work on the mid and back office. And we have seen some good opportunities, for example, just to give you a very simple example. We've moved some of that out of the U.S. into Europe. We have moved some of our fund administration. We are consolidating the number of funds that we run. We one – certainly one of the areas where we have to do a better job in the future. And while the business and the management is focused strongly on is just to reduce the sheer number of funds that we run. We are consolidating this.

We did look at Asia; we have right-sizing Asia. Obviously, we have all our risk business within this and we are restructuring debt. For example we are selling some component of this business, which deals with the management and of our commercial real estate positions. So, I think, there is a lot going on that will result in a much improved cost income ratio. I hope I gave you some ideas of some of the levers that we can pull.
Your second question was the...?
Private Wealth Management.

Yeah. Private Wealth Management, yeah. It was a profitable business. We had around 40 million in EBIT. So it did contribute in this quarter. And also there we see the same effect that we see clients coming back and the business recovering. So, about 30% of the Asset and Wealth Management P&L this quarter came from PW, just to give you a flavor for the number. Thank you, Christopher.
Thanks very much. I appreciate it.
Can we have the next question, please? Thanks Chris.
Your next question is from Mr. Kian Abouhossein, JP Morgan. Please go ahead, sir.

Hi. I have a few very quick ones. First of all, structured credit write-downs of 300 million. Is this the last write-down that should be, we should expect or should we assume there is further clean-ups to come in the next quarters?

Second question IB capital down 13% quarter-on-quarter, risk weighted assets down 4. You're running capital roughly in line with '06 level in the investment bank. Just trying to understand why capital is declining?

Third question IB revenues, you are below the top 3, top 4 players in fixed income equities. But is that something that you are happy with and you will have a more steady business in the fixed income and equity line due to being more flow focused? Or is it something where we expect you should over time take again more risk and as a result you will be in line with some of the top players in terms of revenue generation?

Very quick, one last question, corporate and investment, you had a – sorry, corporate and adjustments, you had a relatively large negative impact. Even if I strip out owned debt, I still don't understand exactly the number, if you could explain it. Thanks.

Okay. On our structured credit mark downs, I think one thing we've learned is not to use the word last throughout the crisis, but we defiantly are getting closer not to see any of them. But again, in the third quarter we were surprised by, for example, this Ocala transaction. These are events, I think, but I would certainly describe it as a more normalized business. I think we definitely believe that the bulk of issues are behind us. But obviously in our recapitalization planning, obviously, we do have some assumptions of further de-risking if you so want it, further work on assets now, that needs to happen at not the increased pace we saw throughout the crisis quarters but we certainly will see some of it coming. But definitely I would say not at the levels that we – that you saw in the beginning – in the leading quarters of the crisis. So that's for that.

The IB revenue is below, we don't share your view. Again, I tried to highlight how strong our IB revenues were in the fixed income area. We had an outstanding performance for Deutsche Bank in the fixed income. We had record levels in the fixed income. Our comparisons show that we are faring very well versus also some of our competitors. So I don't think that's an area that we have any problems on. We don't understand where the perception of this as a weakness comes from, because we really have historic record levels and are developing quite well, despite the fact that, yes, we changed our business model quite considerably in this business area.

On the C&A, large negative. The main issue is obviously the timing differences we have between our M-to-M – mark-to-market versus accrual accounting on our TSY function -- our treasury function – our treasury and how we allocate the treasury cost. You saw some positive effects in the previous quarter and now obviously we saw the considerable swing back in the third quarter. This is an effect that, over time, evens out, because obviously we clean up the different levels. But certainly, based on the risk, based on the swing this number will show, you will always see this kind of volatility in this space, and it can be pretty sizable, especially if we showed a couple of quarters of positive development.

Your last question was the IB capital and that's a more fundamental and strategic question. We have de-risked this business quite considerably.
